item.description: The image of the Virgin of Guadalupe appears on a T-shirt at the Teocintli store in Boyle Heights, Los Angeles. Her face is rendered as a skull with the words "Live life." Photos by Deanna Dent
A shirt with the Virgin of Guadalupe with a skull face that says "live life," inside th Teocintli store in BoyleHeights, Los Angeles, California. Photo by Deanna Dent
A wallet with the image of a Zapatista Virgin of Guadalupe inside the Teocintli store in BoyleHeights, Los Angeles, California. Photo by Deanna Dent
Belt buckles with images of the Virgin are popular with customers of the store.
The Virgin appears even on mouse pads sold at the store. Such items are one way that Mexican-Americans embrace their heritage.
Bracelets like these are popular among Mexican-Americans, not just for decoration, but as a way to express their heritage.
A customer wears a Virgin of Guadalupe necklace. She was looking for T-shirts with the Virgin's image.
The Virgin's image shows up on necklaces, earrings and bracelets.
A sugar mold of the Virgin of Guadalupe is one of the many unusual items at the Teocintli store.
A Virgin of Guadalupe greeting card is displayed among other cards in the store.
This colorful fabric wallet is decorated with an image of the Virgin.
A belt buckle in the shape of a heart contains an image of the Virgin.
The Teocintli store in Boyle Heights is owned by Nico Tonatiuh and his wife Mayra Vasquez. Nico, an artist, creates many of the T-shirts sold in the store.
The Teocintli store in East Los Angeles sits in the midst of a heavily Latino community.
